title: 103_s479
content: The "Small Business Incentive Act of 1993" amends the Securities Act of 1933 to increase the exemption threshold from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 and excludes certain securities from the definition of an investment company. Section 3(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to deem certain issuers as investment companies for specific limitations regarding the purchase and sale of securities issued by registered investment companies. Any issuer whose securities are owned exclusively by qualified purchasers shall be deemed an investment company for specific limitations on purchasing and selling securities issued by registered investment companies. SEC. 4. DEFINITION OF QUALIFIED PURCHASER. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "qualified purchaser" as a natural person with at least $10,000,000 in securities, a person with at least $100,000,000 in securities for their own or others' accounts, or a person determined by the Commission to not need certain protections. The Commission may consider factors such as financial sophistication, net worth, assets owned, relationship with an issuer, or other relevant factors when determining rules for qualified purchasers under the Investment Company Act of 1940. SEC. 5 amends the definition of investment securities under the Investment Company Act of 1940 by excluding securities issued by majority-owned subsidiaries unless they are investment companies. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for economic, business, and industrial development companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph regarding companies not issuing redeemable securities but providing financial or managerial assistance for economic development in a specific state. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new provision stating that at least 80 percent of the securities offered by a company must be held by individuals residing or having a substantial business presence in the state where the securities are being sold. Additionally, the securities must be sold only to accredited investors or other persons permitted by the Commission, and the company cannot purchase securities issued by investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 exempts certain securities from being classified as investment companies, as long as they meet specific criteria such as being rated investment grade or issued by a registered open-end investment company. Despite this exemption, the company must still adhere to certain provisions of the Act as if it were an investment company. The Investment Company Act of 1940 exempts certain securities from being classified as investment companies, as long as they meet specific criteria. Companies can rely on this exemption by filing a notification with the Commission. The exemption may be subject to additional terms and conditions determined by the Commission. SEC. 7 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to change the minimum amount for closed-end investment company exemption to $10,000,000. SEC. 8 revises the definition of eligible portfolio company by setting limits on total assets and capital. SEC. 9 updates the definition of a business development company. SEC. 9 amends the definition of a business development company under the Investment Company Act of 1940, allowing exceptions for providing managerial assistance to certain companies. SEC. 10 updates rules for asset acquisition by business development companies. SEC. 11 introduces amendments related to the capital structure. Amendment to Section 61(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 increases asset coverage requirements for business development companies to 200 percent. However, a business development company may have a lower asset coverage of not less than 110 percent under certain conditions. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment raises asset coverage requirements for business development companies to 200 percent. However, a business development company can have a lower asset coverage of at least 110 percent under specific conditions, including restrictions on issuing senior securities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment requires business development companies to maintain an asset coverage of at least 110 percent for senior securities, with exceptions for regulated investment company status. It is prohibited for a business development company to issue senior securities without provisions to restrict dividends or distributions on common stock. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment mandates that business development companies must have a minimum asset coverage of 110 percent for senior securities, with exceptions for maintaining regulated investment company status. Prohibitions include issuing senior securities without restrictions on dividends or distributions for common stock. The amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 allows business development companies to issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities without accompanying securities, subject to certain conditions and shareholder approval. The amendment allows business development companies to issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities with shareholder approval. The Investment Company Act of 1940 was amended to include "capital structure" in addition to "portfolio" in written statements.
